lesson.title: Intents and Activities
lesson.summary: Build the structure of the Miwok language app!

atoms.title: Intro
atoms.instructor_notes: A collection of the words we would like to add to the app can be found here, Miwok Words Dictionary

question.title: Intro
question.alt_text: Quiz to develop your own mental model of the app

answer.text: ### Thanks for your ideas! There’s no right or wrong answer. There are countless ways for us to build a great Miwok language app. There are good design principles to follow, and we’ll point those out along the way. In the next section, we’ll move forward with one option on how to build the app. If you want to challenge yourself: After this course is complete, you can build a different language app with the user interface that you just proposed. We would love to see your app! By the way, if you’re curious, there are other many other endangered languages with less than 1000 speakers that could be lost, without any intervention.

atoms.title: Import an Existing Project
atoms.text: # Import an Existing Project We’ve created an initial version of the Miwok app for you to start off with, but don’t worry--there’s still plenty left for you to do. When a professional Android developer is joining a new project, it’s very common for the team to already have an existing app that they’re working on. It’s good practice to learn how to read an existing codebase because, oftentimes, you won’t be creating a brand new app from scratch. Follow these instructions to import the Miwok project into Android Studio on your computer. 1. Go to this GitHub project repository link. 2. Click on the “Download zip” button to download the app code. 3. Unzip the downloaded file on your computer so that you have a “Miwok” folder. 4. Open Android Studio. 5. Choose File > Import Project and select the “Miwok” folder. It may take some time for the project to be imported. If you have any issues, check the Troubleshooting notes below. 6. Once that app has successfully imported, run the app on your Android device (phone, tablet, or emulator). It should look like this screenshot. Nothing happens when you click on any of the categories. That’s expected.

atoms.title: Import an Existing Project
atoms.text: 7.Open the Project tab in Android Studio so you can see the file directory.

atoms.title: Import an Existing Project
atoms.caption: Click on Project tab to see file directory

atoms.title: Import an Existing Project
atoms.text:
8.When you’re ready, move onto the quiz. Let’s take a closer look at the codebase for the app (where codebase means all the files in the app). This will help us understand why the app looks and behaves the way it currently does. 

At this point, it’s totally normal if you feel nervous about looking at a new codebase because everything looks so foreign. Now is a good time to practice this skill with some guidance from us.

atoms.title: Import an Existing Project
atoms.instructor_notes: ### Note Ensure that you have the latest extras (Android Studio library, Google Repository, etc) from the Android SDK Manager installed. Ensure that you have all the required SDKs installed from the Android SDK Manager. For this course you will need SDK 15 through SDK 23. If after importing you run into a *gradle not synced issue*, it may be because at the time, the Miwok app was built on an older Android SDK version than what currently exists. To resolve, try these steps: 1. Fork this repository to your GitHub account. 2. Open Android Studio. 3. File -> New -> Project from version control - GitHub 4. Paste a link from your repository of the forked Miwok app, push Clone. 5. Agree the presented terms. Update everything that's asked 6. Launch on the device

question.title: Import an Existing Project
question.alt_text: Quiz to develop your own mental model of the app

atoms.text:
# Checking the build.gradle file

When importing someone else's code into Android Studio, you should normally use the same package versions and target SDK settings that the original code was designed to use. Keeping your own projects up to date is always a good practice, though.
           
Since Android is always releasing new sums of SDK packages, whenever you open or import an old project in Android Studio, you may see an alert saying that the plugin is too old:

atoms.caption: Android Studio will warn you if you import a project whose gradle version is too old

atoms.text:
To resolve this, click on the hyperlink "Fix Gradle version (as part of the update, the Android plugin will be updated to version 2.3.3) Open Documentation" which opens up the documentation with instructions on how to resolve the issue. 

Alternatively, you can update the Gradle version directly by navigating to Gradle Scripts, double-clicking the build.gradle file to open and edit the file:

Make sure you include the most up-to-date versions of:

* compileSdkVersion
* buildToolsVersion
* targetSdkVersion

In addition, in the same file, check if all the dependencies are also updated, for example when the beta version of Constraint Layout beta was released, she would complain about this from an alpha version, since it is now obsolete:
Generally, Android Studio would highlight any outdated packages, such as:

atoms.instructor_notes: In case of confusion, "Android for Beginners" is the course in which you built the birthday card and just java apps.

atoms.title: Andrea Interview
atoms.text:
# Andrea Interview 

Alright, we’ve made great progress so far on the app!

Let your mind relax for a short break, as we go back to Andrea to hear more about her tribe and why building this app is so important to her.

atoms.title: Andrea Interview
atoms.instructor_notes: For more on Andrea's experience being a Miwok woman in tech, read this article!

atoms.title: Andrea Delgado-Olsen
atoms.text: Andrea is part of Native American Women in Computing, an Anita Borg Systers Community.

question.title: Event Listeners in Android
question.alt_text: Quiz about Input Events and Event Listeners with textbox.

atoms.title: What is an Interface?
atoms.instructor_notes: If you’d like a reminder of what “subclass” means, search for this word in the vocab glossary from the last course.

atoms.text:
# Summary 
We just covered a really powerful concept - *Interfaces* - and saw a specific use case - the *OnClickListener Interface* - which helps us listen for when a View is clicked on and then trigger an action.

```java
public interface OnClickListener
void onClick()
```

### Interfaces Recap 
*Interfaces* are similar to classes we've used before; however, they have some large differences. Interfaces don't contain states and methods that are fully implemented and ready for us to use. Instead, interfaces, contain NO states and only method signatures (which specifies the name, return value, and input parameters). Thus, interfaces cannot be instantiated; in order to use them, any class that implements the interface must implement the methods (e.g. build out the behavior) declared in that interface. 

### OnClickListener Interface
In our example in order to use the [OnClickListener Interface](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/view/View.OnClickListener.html), we'll need to implement the [onClick](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/view/View.OnClickListener.html#onClick(android.view.View) method. 

*Why use an interface in this case?*

The Android team knows that many developers will probably want to customize the click behavior, so it wouldn’t make sense to provide default behavior for what happens when a button is clicked. Despite this, the Android team did want to standardize what the method call would be and that the class type would be an OnClickListener. Then they leave the logic inside the onClick method for the developer to write themselves. 

### Further Readings
Interfaces are an important fundamental Java concept. Take some time to solidify the concepts with these resources:
- [Beginners Book - Interface in Java with example programs](https://beginnersbook.com/2013/05/java-interface/)
- [Java Tutorials - Interfaces and Inheritance](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/java/IandI/index.html)

atoms.title: How to Create an Event Listener
atoms.instructor_notes: **Video Correction: ** At 0:36 on the "How to Setup an Event Listener" slide, the text in yellow in point #1 should be *In NumbersClickListener.java...* instead of *In NumbersActivity.java*

atoms.title: How to Create an Event Listener
atoms.text:
#### Video Correction

At 0:36 on the "How to Setup an Event Listener" slide, the text in yellow in point #1 should be *In NumbersClickListener.java...* instead of *In NumbersActivity.java*

---
### More on Click Listeners
I know that was a lot of information to take in. We encourage you to check out a different explanation of click listeners. The second time you hear or read about a topic, the easier it gets, especially if it’s from a different perspective. Furthermore, explaining a concept to someone else helps you understand it better.

Search online for a short post about button click listeners in Android. It can be a StackOverflow.com post, a blogpost, or anything else. 

In the student discussion forum, share the link to the resource. Also include a short description that summarizes your understanding of what you just read.

*Here are some examples:*

* http://stackoverflow.com/questions/8977212/button-click-listeners-in-android 
* http://www.mkyong.com/android/android-button-example/
